metadata.title: Energy related CO2 conversion and utilization: advanced materials/nanomaterials, reaction mechanisms and technologies

sections.text:
CO2 conversion to produce useful fuels/chemicals is a promising route for reducing CO2
emission as well as for exploring the promising energy storage method. To facilitate the research
and development of CO2 conversion, this paper provides a comprehensive overview of CO2 conversions using advanced materials/nanomaterials and technologies for the production of
useful fuels/chemicals. The molecular structure, thermodynamics and kinetics of CO2 are reviewed for the understanding of fundamentals and explaining why C=O double bonds are
difficult to break. The mechanisms and features of various conversion technologies are
summarized and classified into enzymatic, mineralization, photochemical/photo-electrochemical,
thermochemical as well as electrochemical processes. In particular, by comparing
electrochemical conversion technologies at low and high temperatures, CO2 conversion at intermediate temperatures is emphasized. Furthermore, the economic feasibility for CO2 utilization is analyzed with cases for the production of various chemicals/fuels. The technical and
application challenges of CO2 conversion into useful fuels/chemicals are also summarized, composing mainly of: insufficient fundamental understanding, low product selectivity, as well as
low efficiency and stability. To overcome these challenges, future research directions are
proposed in this review.
Key words: carbon dioxide conversion; fuels/chemicals; electrochemical;
materials/nanomaterials

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text:
Continuously increasing global consumption of fossil fuels subsequently has led to the rapid
growth of CO2 concentrations in our atmosphere[1,2]. As one of the major contributors to undesired climate change and environmental destruction, excessive CO2 emissions have greatly affected our world despite it being a necessary material for life and many industrial processes[2-
4]. Thus, it is critical to develop efficient methods for reducing CO2 emissions and explore green and sustainable energy resources[5,6].
For this purpose, several treatment systems to reduce CO2, including more efficient electric
energy production, better energy utilization efficiency, fuel shift (from coal to gas), carbon
capture and storage, and conversion have been proposed by researchers, as shown in Figure 1
[6]. Based on important factors such as cost, energy resource distribution and implementation
time, the reduction and conversion of CO2 into useful fuels/chemicals for utilization is an attractive solution that reduces greenhouse effects and provide effective energy sources[3,7].
CO2 conversion and utilization, as shown in Figure 1, comprise of three main approaches:
chemical/catalytic conversion (chemical process), enzymatic conversion (biological/biochemical
process), and technological utilization (physical process). Here, technological utilization is not
closely related to CO2 conversion because of its physical nature, including compressing, recycling, phase transition, etc. However, it is important for the practical usage of CO2 which includes cereal preservation (bactericide), additives to beverages, food packaging/conversion,
dry-cleaning, extraction, mechanical industries, fire extinguishers, air-conditioning as well as
water treatment[5,6].
CO2 enzymatic conversions (such as photosynthesis)[2,8-11] and mineralization[12-18] are
the most common methods for the conversion/fixation of CO2. CO2 mineralization, from CO2 to inorganic or organic hydro-carbonate (HCO3 - )/carbonate(CO3 2- ) (ΔG＜0), can fixate and store
CO2 effectively but is inefficient. Enzymatic conversions are biological/biochemical processes that occur in organisms such as animals, plants or microorganisms where the conversion
mechanisms in plants are much more complex and difficult to mimic than in bacteria[6].
Chemical conversions comprise of approaches such as photocatalysis and photo-chemical
catalysis[19-25] as well as thermochemical[26-30] and electrochemical[31-40] processes. Of
these, electrochemical conversions are more attractive both in terms of energy efficiency and
cost. This is because of several reasons: (1) the products that are achieved from chemical
synthesis or energy storage can be applied to transportation fuels; (2) the conversion process is
precise and controllable though reaction temperatures and electrode potentials; (3) the
electrochemical conversion systems are modular, compact, highly efficient, on-demand and
scalable; (4) the electricity used in the process can be obtained from clean energy sources with
zero CO2 emissions such as solar, wind, water, nuclear, geothermal, tidal, etc.[4,37,41]. This review will provide detailed descriptions and discussions on the electrochemical conversion
process. The more specific categories of electrochemical catalysis such as low-temperature and
high-temperature electrochemical processes are classified and shown in Figure 1. They will also
be detailed in this review.
It should be mentioned that the conversion of CO2 can be divided into two reaction
categories (Figure 2): one uses less energy supply to convert CO2 into high-carbon organic chemicals with its carbon in an oxidation state of +4 or +3, such conversion reactions also tend
to happen at temperature below 273 K; while the other uses greater energy to reduce CO2 into low-carbon chemicals/fuels with its carbon in the reductive states of +2 or lower. Typical
products are shown in Figure 2 with the two categories. In terms of global market demands, fuels
are significant larger than that of chemicals (12-14 times)[6,42] and the manufacture of fuels
convert significantly greater volumes of CO2 (Gt/y) than that of chemicals (>300 Mt/y).

In its current state in terms of technology and economy, CO2 conversion and utilization are
not mature and efficient enough in meeting the requirements of practical implementation and
commercialization. This can be attributed to major challenges such as low activation/conversion
rates of CO2, insufficient product selectivity, and low material stability in long term operations. Over the last several decades, numerous efforts have been focused on the research and
development of materials and technologies to overcome the above challenges of CO2 conversion. Ever-increasing review papers related to CO2 conversions have been reported [5,6,42,48-50] with the majority focusing on specialized narrow topics. There is a need for a comprehensive
review article for CO2 conversion technologies in the production of useful fuels/chemicals.
This paper is a comprehensive review that focuses on CO2 conversion technologies for the
production of useful fuels/chemicals. Key topics discussed in this paper include the molecular
structure of CO2, the thermodynamics and kinetics of CO2 conversion, and the analysis of the
cause for the low activation/conversion rates of CO2. In regards to CO2 conversion technologies, enzymatic, mineralization, photocatalysis, thermocatalytic and especially electrochemical
processes are classified and summarized. In particular, the mechanisms of CO2 electrochemical conversions including both low-temperature and high-temperature electrochemical processes are
discussed in detail. In addition, an economic analysis of CO2 conversion into useful fuels/chemicals is given. The technical and application challenges are analyzed and summarized
and possible research directions for CO2 conversion technologies to overcome the challenges are proposed to facilitate future research and application.

sections.heading: 2.1 Molecular structure of CO2
sections.text:
CO2 is a linear triatomic molecule with a molecular weight of 44 Dalton. In the molecule,
carbon (C) and oxygen (O) atoms are held together through bonds formed by sharing electrons
and possess strong electrical affinities. It possesses a circular axial symmetry, a center of
symmetry, and a horizontal plane of symmetry [51]. O atoms are better in grabbing the electron
pair than that of C atoms and therefore the electrons are pulled partially away from the C atom,
resulting in the C atom being in a relatively low energy state[52]. Interestingly, the bond length
between C and O in molecular CO2 is 116 pm. This is shorter than that of typical double bonds (e.g. C=O in acetaldehyde, 124 pm) and close to that of triple bonds (e.g. C≡O in carbon
monoxide, 112.8 pm). The bond energy of C=O in CO2 is 803 kJ/mol[53], which is much higher than that of O-H in H2O molecules (463 kJ/mol). These properties seem to be ascribed to the presence of two σ bonds and two π bonds ( 4 3π ) in CO2. two sp-hybridization orbitals are formed
by the mixing of 2s and 2px orbitals in a CO2 molecular [54,55]. Each sp-hybridization orbital of C and a 2pz orbital of O then combine to form an σ bond, and each π bond ( 4 3π ) is formed with a
2py or 2pz orbital, two 2px and a 2py orbital of O. The combination of high symmetry, low polarity and high bond energy leads to the high stability of CO2.
There are three vibrational modes in CO2, a bend vibration and two stretch vibrations
(symmetric and anti-symmetric) as shown in Figure 3. The corresponding frequencies of CO2 with various phases (g, s and aq.) are listed in this figure. In addition to IR (Infrared)
spectroscopy, NMR (Nuclear Magnetic Resonance Spectrometer) spectroscopy can be widely
employed for diagnosis and even quantitative determinations of CO2. 13 C NMR resonance of CO2 in non-polar solvents such as benzene or toluene occurs around 124 ppm, and the resonance is close to 125 ppm when CO2 is performed in aqueous solutions [56,57]. This can be used for the quantification of free CO2 molecules.

sections.heading: 2.3 Kinetics of CO2 conversion
sections.text:
In CO2 conversion reactions, the C atom in the molecule is normally first attacked. In an
addition reaction, the nucleophile first attacks the C atom with a partially positive charge. The
nucleophile can be a neutral species with a lone pair of electrons (e.g., an amine) and can possess
a C-metal σ bond (e.g., a Grignard reagent) or an electron-rich π bond (e.g., a phenolate) [57]. In
such situations, the chemical reactivity of CO2 depends on the polarization of O and C bonds and the kinetics is dominated by both CO2 and nucleophiles. In terms of the chemistry of CO2, the other key feature is its coordination to metals. The electron distribution and molecular geometry
within the CO2 molecule can be changed significantly via the coordination of CO2 to a metal. Generally, the electrons in the bonding orbitals of CO2 can act as an electron donor (referred to as μa-η b , where “a” donates receptor number, and “b” donates donor number), weakening the bond between C and O, leading to increased chemical reactivity. Several CO2-metal complex geometries are shown in Figure 5.

From a thermodynamic standpoint as mentioned above, a reaction is spontaneous when its
Gibbs free energy change is favorable (ΔG＞0). Nevertheless, some reactions may still be non-
spontaneous due to high activation energies. Consequently, these CO2 conversion reactions require a suitable catalyst. Catalysts can lower activation energies and allow or even accelerate
the reaction at suitable temperatures. For example, in the production of ethylene carbonate from
ethylene oxide and CO2, even with remarkably favorable ΔG (-56 kJ/mol) and ΔH (-144 kJ/mol), a suitable catalyst is required for the reaction to occur. This can be interpreted with Figure 6
where four types of CO2 conversion reactions (A-D) are defined. The reaction pathway energy diagrams are divided into two groups also shown in Figure 6: (a) the processes of reactions A and
B both of which possess a negative Gibbs free energy change (ΔG＜0); and (b) the processes of
reactions C and D both of which possess a positive Gibbs free energy change (ΔG＞0).
In group (a) as mentioned above, the activation energy (ΔG * ) of Reaction B is much higher
than that of A, thus, Reaction A is expected to occur without the need of a catalyst whereas a
catalyst is necessary for Reaction B due to its significant activation energy. The synthesis of
sodium salicylate from CO2 and sodium phenolate is a good example of Reaction A and the production of ethylene carbonate from CO2 and ethylene oxide is a good example of Reaction B. One thing to note here is that simply promoting the reaction temperature may not always be
effective in overcoming the activation barrier as the ΔG will be positive if the ΔS of the reaction
is negative.
In group (b), with regards to Reaction C in Figure 6, the ΔG * is slightly higher than ΔrG (the
Gibbs free energy change of CO2 conversion reactions), thus catalysts are not needed, but the removal of the formed products is challenging. Therefore, the reaction equilibrium will shift positively or even not occur. Comparing with Reaction C, the ΔG * of Reaction D is much higher
than its ΔrG. This is the most challenging situation and unfortunately, it is common in CO2 conversions. Consequently, an effective catalyst for reducing ΔG * is necessary that can facilitate
the reaction at a lower and more suitable temperature because lower reaction temperatures can
contribute to a decrease in ΔrG and an increase in equilibrium constant for the reaction. Having said this, it is recognized that poor catalytic activity and/or insufficient stability of catalysts are
the largest challenges in CO2 conversions (especially in CO2 electro-reduction)[48]. Thus, CO2 conversion is also difficult from a kinetics standpoint[60].
Figure 6. Reaction pathway energy diagrams for reactions of carbon dioxide (Here ΔrG is the Gibbs free energy change of CO2 conversion reactions). Reproduced with permission from Ref.[57]. Copyright 2015, Elsevier B.V..
As mentioned above, CO2 is thermodynamically and kinetically stable, making its
conversions to other chemicals/fuels difficult. However, CO2 can be attacked by nucleophiles and electron-donating reagents ascribe to the electron deficiency of carbonyl carbons[50].
Therefore, the conversion of CO2 is achievable in practice despite technological barriers[5]. Typical approaches, especially for the production of fuels with high energy exchange, are
detailed as follows.

sections.heading: 2.4 Enzymatic conversion of CO2
sections.text:
Enzymatic conversion of CO2 is one of the most common approaches for converting CO2
into organic materials in nature; being necessary for life and biological evolution. Compared to
chemical processes of CO2 conversion, enzymatic conversion of CO2 can provide an efficient and more environmentally friendly solution due to its excellent specificity and selectivity[61-63].
In regards to the enzymatic conversion of CO2 in cells, there are major approaches such as
the Calvin cycle, the 3-hydroxypropionate cycle, and the reductive citric acid cycle. The Calvin
cycle; the most significant biosynthetic cycle in nature, is widely used in photosynthesis in
plants, cyanobacteria, algae, etc. [64]. The process of converting hydro-carbon chemicals/fuels
(CnHm) to CO2 is exothermal and easily facilitated due to a negative Gibbs free-energy (ΔG＜0).
On the contrary, the conversion of CO2 to carbohydrates (CnHmOx) via photosynthesis is energy intensive (ΔG＞0). Figure 7a shows the basic conception of typical photosynthesis, which
contains a light reaction from H2O to O2 using solar energy and a dark reaction (Calvin cycle) from CO2 to organic substance such as glucose[65]. Obviously, the key process for CO2 conversion is the Calvin cycle as shown clearly in Figure 7b which can be divided into three
stages. First, the reaction from CO2 and 1,5-bisphosphate ribulose to 3-phosphoglycerate is facilitated by the first key enzyme 1,5-bisphosphate ribulose bisphosphate carboxylase. Then,
1,3-diphosphoglycerate will be generated from 3-phosphoglycerate and a Pi further producing 3-
phosphate glyceraldehyde by the second key enzyme phosphoglyceral-dehyde dehydrogenase.
Finally, 5-phosphate ribulose is produced from 5/6 of the generated 3-phosphate glyceraldehyde
and further transformed into 1,5-bisphosphate ribulose, which forms the reactant with CO2 in the next cycle. Meanwhile, the other part of the generated 3-phosphate glyceraldehyde will
transform to organic substances such as sugar, fatty acids, and amino acids as shown in Figure
7b. In the process described above, the NADPH (nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide phosphate)
is used as a proton carrier and a hydrogen source, and the transformation of ATP (adenosine
triphosphate) into ADP (adenosine diphosphate) provides energy.
Figure 7. Process of photosynthesis[66] and the Calvin cycle[61]. Reproduced with permission from Ref. [61,66]. Copyright 2012, Elsevier B.V. and Copyright 2015, Royal Society of Chemistry, respectively.

sections.heading: 2.5 Mineralization process of CO2 conversion
sections.text:
The mineralization of CO2 is a long term storage solution that imitates the natural CO2
absorption process of silicate minerals. This process involves the carbonation of silicate minerals
to form stable carbonate minerals[13,17,18]. Similar to CO2 reduction in carbon capture and sequestration (CCS), CO2 mineralization can be widely used in converting CO2 to chemicals[85]. W. Seifritz [86] proposed the disposal of CO2 using silicates, in which CO2 and CaSiO3 can be transformed into Ca 2+ , HCO3 - and SiO2 in the presence of water therefore reducing CO2. Natural silicate minerals such as serpentine (Mg3Si2O5(OH)4(s)), olivine (forsterite, Mg2SiO4(s)), wollastonite (CaSiO3(s)), talcum, pyroxenes and amphiboles can trap CO2 to form environmentally stable solid carbonates that can be used as building materials, flame retardants
and so forth[87-90]. The typical reactions can be described as follows[91,92]:

Commonly used processes for CO2 mineralization can be summarized into two routes as
shown in Figure 10: (1) direct (single-step) processes[12], that is, direct carbonation of silicate

A challenge for direct carbonation processes is that the reaction rates are very slow at room
temperature. The reaction can be accelerated with elevated temperatures and pressures but this is
energy intensive[92]. Lackner et al.[94] found that the carbonation conversion efficiency of serpentine particles was 25%-30% at 500℃ and 3.4×107 Pa. Compared to gas-solid carbonation
conversions, the chemical kinetics of carbonation using a direct aqueous process is much
higher[95,96]. Researchers have reported that the conversion rates can be increased by using
certain aqueous solutions such as NaHCO3 and NaCl solutions. This has attracted much attention[91]. Conversion levels can be further enhanced by using more suitable reactor types in
which strong intra-particle mechanical effects can exist, such as a fluidized bed proposed by
Bhardwaj et al. for the acceleration of CO2 mineralization of serpentine. As shown in Figure 11[18], a CO2 conversion level of 40% and a mineral conversion level of 50% can be achieved in 8 min at 90 ℃ and atmospheric pressure (0.1 MPa).
Figure 11. Schematic for (a) the process of CO2 mineralization using fluidized bed and (2) the formation process of carbonate-silica product on the surface of serpentinite particles. TGA, thermogravimetric analysis; MS, mass spectrometry. Reproduced with permission from Ref. [18]. Copyright 2016, American Chemical Society
Furthermore, to improve aqueous rock dissolution and activation of mineral particles,
chemical, thermal and mechanical pre-treatments were performed on aqueous process routes,
namely, the indirect (multistep) process, including extracting magnesium and calcium from
minerals with intermediate and carbonation processes. Commonly used intermediate chemicals
include weak acids (such as citrates and oxalates), HCl and NaOH solutions[87,88]. A case in
point is a process proposed by Kakizawa et al.[97] and Yuen et al.[15] as shown in Figure 12.
Their proposed process includes two steps (1) the dissolution of calcium silicate by acetic acid
and (2) the carbonation of calcium acetate. The recovery of acetic acid can also be achieved in
this approach, which is similar to a high chemical potential catalyst. In comparison to direct
processes, the final products in indirect conversion routes tend to be purer. However, many
challenges need to be addressed to lower the energy input and the unrecovered intermediate
chemicals. If these challenges can be minimized, these routes will have better prospects.
Figure 12. Schematic of indirect pressure carbonation process. Reproduced with permission from Ref. [15]. Copyright 2016, Springer.
Obviously, various value-added mineral products can be generated via CO2 mineralization.
For instance, Chang et al. [13] controlled the polymorphism of CaCO3 to generate high valueadded mineral carbonation products as shown in Figure 1a, which could further lower the total
cost of the CCS process. Another case proposed by Xie et al. [98] is mineralization of CO2 and separation of Ca 2+ /Mg 2+ ions from hard water to some high valuable carbonates. Meanwhile,
industrial alkaline solid wastes and waste water can also be used as feedstocks for CO2 mineralization. This is environmentally friendly[17,99]. Researchers found that the carbonation
of industrial waste (such as steel slag, carbide slag, waste cement/concrete and blast furnace slag)
and by-products containing calcium or magnesium can not only reduce energy consumption but
also reduce local pollution[100-102]. Thus, the carbonation of industrial waste or by-products
has received growing attention in academic investigations and even commercial applications
[103-105].
Interestingly, although CO2 cannot be transformed into fuels/chemicals via mineralization
for energy storage, electricity can be generated during the mineralization process because the
conversion reactions are exothermic and occur spontaneously (ΔG＜0) [106]. As shown in
Figure 13, a novel technique to generate electricity using exchange membranes was proposed by

The mineralization of CO2 is a good choice for sustainable, long term development due to
its environmentally friendly process and the outstanding thermal stability of its product

need to be resolved through further technological developments.
2.6 Photocatalytic and photo-electrochemical processes of CO2 conversion
Over the past few decades, much researches have been carried out to investigate the
photocatalytic and photo-electrochemical processes of CO2 conversion into carbon-based fuels. In 1979, although oxide and non-oxide semiconductor particles such as TiO2, ZnO, CdS, etc. have yet to be developed, Honda et al. still achieved CO2 photocatalytic reduction to hydrocarbons[109]. Since then, continuous studies on photocatalytic CO2 reduction have been carried out and reported[24,110-112].
The fundamental process of CO2 photocatalytic reduction is shown in Figures 14 and 15. In
the mechanism, when catalysts (such as semiconductor material) are exposed to photon
irradiation, electrons can be excited from its balance band (VB) to a conduction band (CB),
leaving a positively-charged electron hole in the CB simultaneously. These so-called photogenerated electron (e - ) - hole (h + ) pairs are then separated from each other and moved to active
sites at the catalyst surface vigorously. With the assistant of these photo-generated electrons, CO2 is reduced into various useful fuels (e.g. CO, CH4, CH3OH etc.) with or without H2O at the catalyst surface. The products are different depending on the number of participative electrons in the chemical reaction. For instance, CO or HCOOH is formed with 2e - , while the generation of CH3OH needs 6e - and CH4 needs 8e - . Noteworthy; as illustrated in Figure 15, the duration of the excited state of the electron-hole pairs can be prolonged by establishing an electric field at the
semiconductor-electrolyte interface because the recombination of electron and hole will be
hindered by an electric field. Through this, CO2 can be reduced through a photo-electrocatalysis process [82].

For the photocatalysis process, the activity of the catalyst plays a critical role in governing
its kinetics. Here, three main categories of common photocatalyst materials are reviewed as
follow: semiconductor materials, graphene-based nano-catalyst, and organometallic complexes.
Semiconductor materials include various types of inorganic binary compounds, such as
TiO2, ZnO, CdS and SiC, etc. [25,114,115]. It has been suggested that at the surface of a semiconductor, the charge transfer kinetics between the photo-generated carriers (e - and h + ) is
determined by the correlation of energy levels between the semiconductor and the redox agents
in the solution[109]. This hypothesis is illustrated in Figure 16, which shows the energy
correlation between various semiconductor catalysts and the redox potentials of different species.
It is accepted that the performance efficiency of semiconductor photocatalysts is influenced by:
(1) the width of the semiconductor band gap, which is related to the absorption scope of photons
to generate electron-hole pairs; (2) the effective separation of electron-hole pairs from each other
and migration to the surface; and (3) the amount and availability of active sites that can
participate in photocatalytic reactions.
To improve the conversion efficiency and selectivity of photocatalysis process, various
semiconductor materials have been further investigated [63,115-118]. As a typical representative
among those proposed photocatalysts, TiO2 has been extensively studied over the last several decades due to its environmental friendliness and low-cost [72,119-121]. More recently, Low et
al. [122] summarized numerous approaches of surface modification of TiO2, which include impurity doping, metal deposition, heterojunction construction and so forth. The effects of TiO2 surface point defects have been reviewed by Zhao et al. [121], which offered some insights into
the design of highly efficient semiconductor photocatalysts for CO2 conversion. Besides, The CO2 reduction mechanisms and pathways on the surface of TiO2 have also been presented. As shown in Figure 1i and j, Lee et al. [47] investigated the electron-induced dissociation of CO2 adsorbed at the oxygen vacancy defect on the TiO2(110) surface using an advanced method, scanning tunneling microscopy (STM). The electron-transfer process at STM tip/CO2/TiO2 interface has been proposed. Furthermore, another advanced experimental method, Time-
Resolved IR Spectroscopy (TRIR), was performed to reveal the mechanism of catalyst
photoreduction, which is initiated by ultrafast electron injection into TiO2, followed by a rapid (ps-ns) and sequential two-electron oxidation [123]. Nevertheless, compared to thermodynamic
potentials, experimental evidence of the photocatalytic mechanisms of semiconductor materials
still remains indistinct. Some more advanced experimental methods such as in-situ time-resolved
spectroscopy is implemented to further reveal the key governing catalytic performances in
semiconductors.
Figure 16. A schematic illustration of the energy correlation between semiconductor catalysts and redox couples in water. CB (conduction band), VB (valence band). Reproduced with permission from Ref. [109]. Copyright 1979, Macmillan Journals Ltd.
As a typical example in carbon based nanoparticles, graphene-based composite
photocatalysts have attracted increasing attention in recent years, which is another type of
potential catalyst material[19,21,22,124,125]. Although graphene seems to play a synergistic role
in most composite graphene-semiconductor photocatalysts, it can induce significant performance
enhancements for CO2 conversions when compared to bare semiconductors. As an example, Liang et al.[114] prepared a series of SEG-P25 (graphene-TiO2 P25 with the appropriate addition of solvent-exfoliated graphene) composites that exhibited significantly higher photoactivities
than that of blank P25 for CO2 reduction under visible light or UV irradiation. Ong et al.[25] also reported that nitrogen doped-TiO2-001/graphene (N-TiO2-001/GR) composites synthesized by in-situ photocatalytic reduction exhibited a 3.7 mmol gcatalyst -1 yield of CH4 after reacting for 10 hours. This was about 10 times higher than that of TiO2-001. In addition, they also found that the doping of graphene can notably improve the CO2-reducing performance of C3N4[21], while Yu et al.[124] demonstrated that the reduced graphene oxide-CdS exhibited notably elevated visible-
light photocatalytic activities for the reduction of CO2 to CH4 as compared to bare CdS. Low et al.[22] summarized the advantages of the performance enhancements by coupling graphene with
a photocatalyst. They declared that in these graphene-semiconductor photocatalysts, the
semiconductor acts as a light harvester and the graphene acts as an efficient co-catalyst that can
act as an electron conductive platform, in which the energy level is lower than the CB of the
semiconductor, lowering the energy barrier for electronic transition and CO2 reduction.
In addition to acting as a co-catalyst, some reports also highlighted the intrinsic activity of
graphene and its derivatives, such as graphene oxide (GO)[126-128]. With the participation of
GO, CO2 with H2O vapor can convert into CH3OH under simulated solar light irradiation as reported by Hsu et al.[129]. Notably, the photocatalytic conversion rates of CO2 can reach 0.172 μmol g cat -1 h -1
. This is 6 times higher than that of TiO2 P25, a state-of-the-art photocatalyst.
Furthermore, they also reported that Cu decoration on the surface of GO can surprisingly enhance the solar fuel formation rate to 6.4 μmol g cat -1 h -1 , which is even higher than that of
blank GO[130]. Additionally, Kumar et al.[23,131] reported that a series of photo-responsive
metal-organic complexes based on GO supports can also significantly improve photocatalytic
activities of CO2 reduction compared to GO. Although a unified theory to explain these enhancing mechanisms in different systems remains unclear, all these findings above
demonstrate that graphene is a promising photocatalyst for achieving high-efficiency
photochemical CO2 conversions.
Photocatalysis CO2 reduction can be also achieved with the assistance of several
organometallic complexes. Because this process can be regarded as an artificial simulation for
photosynthesis catalytic CO2 reduction in nature, researchers are searching for a photocatalyst that resembles chlorophyll, which can effectively fix CO2 in natural light conditions as well as facilitate CO2 reduction to hydrocarbons. In general, organometallic complexes can be divided into three categories by its photoelectric features: (1) the complex is photo-active but not
catalytic-active, which can only act as an electron transfer medium; (2) the complex is catalytic-
active but not photo-active, which is required to work together with organic or inorganic
photosensitizers; and (3) the complex is catalytic-active and photo-active, such as a series of Ru(bpy)2(CO)X n+ complexes (bpy: 2, 2’-bipyridine, X: CO, Cl, H, etc.)[132]. It has been found that the second type of materials (catalytic-active but not photo-active) have the highest quantum
efficiency and product selectivity in general. Therefore, a combination of this type of material
with semiconductors is a promising method to achieve high-efficient and high-selective CO2 conversions. For instance, Sato et al.[133] combined p-type N-Ta2O5 with [Ru(dcbpy)(bpy)(CO)2] 2+ and [Ru(dcbpy)2(CO)2] 2+ to implement CO2 reduction to CO in a triethanolamine-MeCN solution. The light quantum photon yield here was 1.9 with 75%
selectivity at a wavelength of 405 nm.
As a combination of photocatalytic reduction and electrocatalytic reduction, photo-
electrocatalytic CO2 reduction is expected to possess advantages of both approaches to achieve efficient and highly selective conversions of CO2[134]. For instance, Kaneco et al.[135] carried out CO2 photo-electrocatalytic reductions with catalysts of p-InP modified with different metals (Pb, Ag, Au, Pd, Cu, Ni) in LiOH-CH3OH electrolyte while Barton et al.[136] used photoelectrocatalytic reaction devices to achieve CO2 reduction to CH3OH. Here, narrow band single crystal p-GaP (111) semiconductors were used as photocathodes in solutions containing pyridine
salt. Surprisingly, the current efficiency is 100% at a reduction potential of -0.3 V (vs SCE).
Recently, a conformal TiO2 film on a black silicon (b-Si) photoanode was presented by Yu et al. [112] for remarkably enhancing the efficiency and stability of photo-electrochemical process A
photocurrent density of 32.3 mA cm −2 at an external potential of 1.48 V versus reversible
reference electrode (RHE) in 1 M NaOH electrolyte could be achieved. This research provided a
novel insight into photo-electrochemical water splitting and even CO2 conversion. To improve the conversion efficiency and product selectivity, various hybrid catalysts have also been
developed, Zhao et al. [137] summarized the recent studies on semiconductor/metal complex co-
catalyst systems. Additionally, another interesting example, a photo-cathode with a Ru(II)−Re(I)
complex photocatalyst and a CoOx/TaON photoanode was presented by Sahara et al. [138] to conversion of CO2 with high selectivity and efficiency, which may be the first example of a molecular and semiconductor photocatalyst hybrid-constructed photo-electrochemical cell for
CO2 reduction under visible-light in the presence of water. Aside from synergistic effect, controlling the nanostructures of catalysts or electrodes can also dramatically increase CO2 reduction reaction rate. For example, Song et al. [139] studied an Si photo-electrodes with a
nano-porous Au thin film for photo-electrochemical CO2 to CO conversion with highly efficiency and selectivity, while Kong et al. [140] demonstrated a directed assembly of
nanoparticle catalysts on vertical nanowires photo-electrodes for similar conversion under
illumination.
According to the discussion in this section, photoelectric catalytic reduction of CO2 can be
achieved through many approaches. The key research objective in this field is to rationally
design a photoelectric catalyst through a combination of photocatalytic and electrocatalytic
techniques to achieve high-efficiency and high-selectivity of CO2 reduction. To meet this goal, the mechanisms of photo-electrocatalytic CO2 reduction, the specific collaborative effect mechanisms as well as the reaction device structures still need to further explored and developed.
Particularly, understanding and designing different reaction routes for CO2 photocatalytic reduction in different reaction media are essential in this field and will provide guidance for
high-efficient and high-selective CO2 conversions.

sections.heading: 2.7 Thermochemical process of CO2 conversion
sections.text:
Among various approaches to catalytically convert CO2 into high calorific fuels, the
thermocatalytic process (especially the process of CO2 hydrogenation) is an important alternative with a long history of research and application [50,141-144]. The conversion process is
simplified into a schematic diagram as shown in Figure 17. Based on the structural features of
CO2 molecules, it is more feasible for CO2 to accept electrons from catalyst sites than to donate them. Therefore, to achieve efficient thermocatalytic conversions of CO2, electrons must be injected into the antibonding orbital of CO2. Therefore, as a reducing agent and a high-energy material, H2 (g) is necessary for the thermocatalytic conversion of CO2 and it needs to be dissociated into the atomic absorbed H* in active sites[27].
As a common process in the thermochemical route for CO2 conversions, hydrogenation of
CO2 was first observed by Sabatier and Senderens [145] in the early twentieth century[146]. After that, numerous research have been conducted on this topic[27,29,30,147]. The catalytic
conversion process that occurs in the solid-gas interface as shown in Figure 17 are commonly
investigated, especially for the conversion process with VIIIB metals on various oxide supports.
The generation of the three main fuels/chemicals including methanol (CH3OH), formic acid (HCOOH) and carbon monoxide (CO) are discussed in this section.
Figure 17. Simplified schematic diagram of thermocatalytic conversion of CO2 with H2 feed gas.

sections.text:
As an alternative fuel and feedstock in many industrial processes, CH3OH from CO2
conversion have been studied extensively [148-154]. Wang et al.[155] have reviewed various
catalytic systems for CH3OH synthesis via CO2 hydrogenation, emphasizing on catalytic reactivity and reaction mechanisms. Among all metals, Cu is mainly investigated in laboratory
and used in industrial applications due to its superior catalytic performances. It is always used
together with various modifiers such as Ti, Zn, Ce, Al, Si and so on as shown in Table
4[148,149,156-158]. A typical case in point is the Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalytic system for industrial CH3OH synthesis from CO2 and H2 at moderate conditions (200-300℃,5-10 MPa)[159,160].

Generally, there are three proposed transformation mechanisms, including the HCOO/r-
HCOO mechanism, the reverse water gas shift mechanism (RWGS) and the trans-COOH
mechanism [27]. Here the reaction pathway of the HCOO/r-HCOO mechanism on Cu is
presented. Kakumoto et al.[170] proposed that the pathway of CO2 hydrogenation was in accordance with the HCOO mechanism: CO2 → HCOO*→ H2COO* → CH2O* → CH3O*→ CH3OH. However, a revised HCOO mechanism as shown in Figure 18 as proposed by Grabow and Mavrikakis[29] seems much more preferable due to the fact that the activation energy for

Therefore, the r-HCOO mechanism is preferable with Cu (111). sections.heading: 2.7.2 CO2 hydrogenation to HCOOH
sections.text:
Formic acid (or HCOOH) is a chemical widely-used in many industries such as textiles,
rubber, food, pharmaceuticals and so on. The synthesis of HCOOH via CO2 hydrogenation has attracted increasing interests since the early 1990s[171]. The first case related to the direct
synthesis of HCOOH via CO2 hydrogenation was reported by Farlow and Adkins[172] in 1935 using a Raney nickel as a catalyst under conditions of 80-150℃ and 20-40 MPa. Up to now, the
recognized catalytic systems for this conversion process (CO2 + H2 → HCOOH) are transition
metals of groups VIII to IIB, such as Ru, Rh, Pd, Ir, Ni, Fe, Co, Cu, Ag and so forth[173-178].
Some cases are shown as follows.
With respect to Rh, Musashi and Sakaki[179] presented a theoretical investigation of the
mechanisms of HCOOH generation via CO2 hydrogenation in Rh catalytic systems, especially for the differences between Rh(I), Rh(II) and Rh(III) complexes. There are two steps for this
reaction, the first one is the insertion of CO2 into Rh-H bonds. The second step has two possible routes, one route includes isomerization, reductive elimination and oxidative addition in turn; the
other route contains isomerization and metathesis reactions. The rate-determining step for both
routes is the insertion of CO2 into Rh-H bonds.
Ru complexes tend to offer excellent activity and selectivity for HCOOH generation. These
complexes attract large numbers of studies both theoretical and experimental[180-182]. A
reaction pathway related to CO2 hydrogenation for HCOOH generation using ruthenium dihydride catalysts is shown in Figure 19[183,184]. Results from simulations and experiments
show two possible sequences of intermediates in this reaction, indicating that the insertion of
CO2 with a relatively low activation barrier is a rapid process with the rate-determining step being the insertion of H2 into the formate-Ru complex. Compared to the trans isomer (4, 5.5%), the cis isomer (1, 94.5%) is predominant with the activation energy (Ea) of the rate-determining step being higher[184]. Furthermore, Rohmann et al.[180] recently reported a novel catalyst [Ru
(Acriphos) (PPh3) (Cl) (PhCO2)] (Acriphos = 4,5-bis (diphenylphosphino) acridine) for HCOOH generation from CO2 in dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) and DMSO/H2O. As a result, the turnover numbers and turnover frequencies have reached 4200 and 260 h -1 respectively.

In addition to the catalytic system, the reaction media such as water, organic solvents, ionic
liquids or supercritical CO2 is also an important factor in determining the conversion rate[175,185]. For instance, due to their unique properties, ionic liquids are used in CO2 hydrogenation systems as shown in Figure 20[186,187]. Zhang et al. reported that superior
activity and selectivity can be obtained during CO2 hydrogenation for HCOOH generation by combining a Ru related catalyst and a basic ionic liquid. Moreover, other catalytic systems
related to Ru such as Ru/TiO2 [181,188], Ru nanoparticles[189] in ionic liquid etc. are also being studied.

thermochemical conversion approach to synthesizing various fuels/chemicals. The generated
syngas in this approach can be used to produce a wide range of products such as higher alkanes
via Fischer-Tropsch synthesis[28]. It is known that Fischer and Tropsch[190] first studied CO2 reforming of methane (DRM) process using catalysts of Ni and Co in 1928. The phenomenon of
carbon deposition was observed during this investigation, leading to the severe deactivation of
the catalysts. Since then, numerous studies have been conducted to deal with this issue to
improve the efficiency and stability of this reforming process[28,147,191-193].

Kinetic analysis is also necessary to understand the reaction processes of DRM. The reaction

sections.heading: 2.8 Electrochemical process of CO2 conversion
sections.text:
Multiple pathways have been investigated and proposed by researchers for the
electrochemical conversion of CO2 as shown in Figure 23[35]. These pathways can be divided into two categories: high-temperature (＞800 ℃) conversions using gaseous techniques such as
solid oxide cells (SOC, including solid oxide fuel cell (SOFC) and solid oxide electrolysis cell
(SOEC))[1]; and low-temperature (＜200 ℃) conversions using aqueous and non-aqueous
techniques such as transition metal electrodes in liquid electrolytes (eg. methanol, acetonitrile,
etc.). The variety of products generated with high-temperature conversions is much less than that
of low-temperature conversions, whereas the selectivity and efficiency of SOCs are generally
superior to that of low-temperature conversions. Therefore, catalysts in low-temperature
conversions of CO2 need to have high selectivity and can speed up the reaction rate. These electrochemical CO2 conversion pathways will be discussed in this section.

the main points for understanding CO2 electrochemical conversion at low-temperatures.

In consideration of the stable molecule structure, hybridization form, thermodynamics and
even kinetics of CO2, the conversion of CO2 into CO is normally difficult as shown in Figure 25 (left). It can be clearly seen that the intermediate state in CO2 conversions is •CO2 - and that the activation energy of this conversion reaction without catalysts is too high. Therefore, during the
electrochemical conversion process, the provided overpotential (ηno cat.) is relatively high to activate C=O bonds in CO2 molecules. Using a catalyst, the overpotential will be significantly reduced. Energetic efficiency is an important parameter to determine the recoverable energy
contained in the product, which is closely related to the energy cost of production. The Faraday
and energy efficiencies can be calculated using the equations as shown in Figure 25 (right). It has
been recognized that high energy efficiency is attainable through a combination of low
overpotentials and high Faraday efficiency[37].

Although there are challenges related to CO2 electrocatalytic reductions, such as low
catalytic activity and insufficient stability, electrochemical catalysts for CO2 conversion has attracted great attention. Particularly, transition metals and post-transition metals are frequently
studied in literature. Normally, onset overpotentials are all lager than 300 mV even in cases with
electrocatalysts[42]. On bulk metal surfaces, some display high selectivity for HCOOH (Sn, In,
Pb, Hg)[201,202] or CO (Au, Ag)[203,204]. Cu has gain large interests for its high selectivity for

reduced to a formyl species (*CHO) or a *COH species, which is then further reduced to
methane. In the C2 pathway, the key C−C bond-making step at low overpotentials is a CO dimerization step mediated by electron transfers rendering a *C2O2 − intermediate. In general, insufficient knowledge of the reduction mechanisms and insufficient understanding of the active

A case in point is where SnO2-CuO nanocomposites were synthesized and its high catalytic activity for CO2 electro-reduction was investigated. 2.8.2 High-temperature electrochemical process of CO2 conversion
A SOC is a device that can convert electrical energy into chemical energy in SOEC mode
and convert chemical energy into electrical energy in SOFC mode[1,219-221] as shown in
Figure 28. In case of SOEC mode (the red arrow in Figure 28a), the SOC includes an anode (oxygen electrode), a dense solid electrolyte (ionic conductor) and a cathode (fuel electrode). H2O (g) or/and CO2(g) is fed into the cathode and oxide ions are conducted from the cathode across the dense electrolyte to the anode. At the anode, oxygen is then evolved and syngas is produced at the cathode. The CO2 used can be captured from industrial and power plant
emissions and the resulting syngas can be transformed into synthetic fuels. This process can
also utilize redundant electricity from nuclear and clean energy sources. In regards to SOFC
mode (the blue arrow in Figure 28a), the cathode is the oxygen electrode and the anode is the
fuel electrode, with the process being conversed. Therefore, the produced fuels can be used to
generate energy in this mode.
In order to enhance the efficiency and stability of high temperature electrochemical
conversion of CO2, advanced materials/nanomaterials should be considered in advance. Main components of SOC include fuel/oxygen electrodes, electrolyte, interconnect and cell sealing,
among which, fuel/oxygen electrodes play the critical roles in numerous studies of SOC. Irvine
et al. [219] has summarized the materials/nanomaterials and microstructures of electrodes. It is
known that the functionalities including electronic conduction, ionic conduction and catalytic
activity are essential for an electrode. One or more functionality/functionalities can be provided
by some materials such as metal, fluorite and perovskites, double perovskites and Ruddlesden–
Popper (RP) phase oxides [44,222-226]. Large numbers of specific advanced materials/
nanomaterials (e.g. Ni-YSZ (yttria-stabilized zirconia), Ni-SDC (Ni-Sm0.2Ce0.8O2-δ), La0.8Sr0.2CoO3 (LSC), LaSrMnO3 (LSM), Ba0.5Sr0.5Co0.8Fe0.2O3-δ (BSCF), LaBaCo2O5+δ, PrBaCo2O5+δ, etc.) and technologies in co-electrolysis of H2O and CO2 using SOC have been introduced in detail in our review paper published in Chem. Soc. Rev. [1]. In this section, the
general introduction of SOC in SOEC mode will be emphasized.
To improve the chemical output of a single-cell SOEC system, the active cell area must be
enlarged[227-229]. Thus, a stack consisting of multiple cells is necessary. The structure of SOEC
from stack to single cell and even nano/micro-structured materials are shown in Figure 28b (in
case of planar cell). Interconnects must be added in a stack to provide adequate electrical
connections between the oxygen electrode of one single cell and the fuel electrode of the
adjacent one. SOC cell/stack can be applied for applications ranging from watt-sized devices to
multi-megawatt power sources as shown in Figure 28a. Although many are still in developmental
stages of hardware demonstration, prototype (pre-commercial stage), and design (conceptual
stage, ＞1MW), in recent years, significant advancements associated with performance
(including degradation and durability), fabrication scale-up, miniaturization and fuel utilization
have been made in the technological areas of SOC [230-232].

Compared to separate H2O or CO2 electrolysis processes, CO2/H2O co-electrolysis using SOC at high-temperatures have greater potentials in the future for efficiency improvements and
cost reductions because it has better energy efficiencies with less electrolysis steps, lower
energy consumption, as well as the fact that it only needs one reactor to operate[229,234,235].
The comparable performances for steam and co-electrolysis are shown in Figure 29. It can be
seen clearly that there is no obvious change of ASR (area-specific resistance) for H2O electrolysis and H2O/CO2 co-electrolysis, which are much lower than that of CO2 electrolysis[220,236]. Noteworthy, nickel oxidation may occur in electrodes such as Ni-YSZ

The produced syngas (H2 + CO) is an effective large scale energy carrier that can be further processed by Fischere-Tropsch (F-T) synthesis[237] to generate liquid fuels or chemicals. In
addition, in the reversible mode, the produced fuels can generate power within the same SOC
device [230]. In the opinion of Minh and Mogensen[230], SOC is believed to have the following
features: (1) capability (for different functions), (2) compatibility (environmentally compatible),
(3) flexibility (can be integrated with various energy sources, sustainable energies especially), (4)
affordability (competitiveness in cost) and (5) adaptability (suitable for different local energy
needs or variety of applications).
However, the technical maturity of electrolysis/co-electrolysis for CO2 conversion and utilization using SOC at high-temperature is still insufficient in meeting the requirements for
practical implementation or commercialization. The requirements of materials including
electrode and electrolyte used in SOC are much higher, such as high conductivities, compatible
thermal expansion coefficients, dimensional /mechanical /chemical /thermal stabilities, and cell
integration. Due to this, degradation of materials in a serious issue in SOC cells or stacks, with
the issues being worsened at high temperatures especially. These degradation issues in SOCs
include delaminating and Cr poisoning of oxygen electrodes, Redox stability, as well as SiO2 poisoning of fuel electrodes. Therefore, more efforts need to be taken to overcome those issues.
In summary, electrochemical conversions are promising both in terms of energy efficiency
and cost due to the reasons as discussed above. However, there are still limitations such as low
energy efficiencies caused by slow reduction kinetics of CO2, insufficient activity and stability of materials, low selectivity of products especially at low temperatures, insufficient fundamental
understanding and so forth. These limitations are summarized in detail by Qiao et al.[48].
Therefore, more efforts need to be taken for further development of electrochemical conversions
of CO2.

It should be noted that all economic analysis in literature is based on normal electricity
costs. If redundant electricity from clean energy and/or nuclear sources is used, the results of the

sections.heading: 3. Technical and application challenges of CO2 conversion to useful
sections.text:
fuels/chemicals
In regards to CO2 conversion into useful fuels/chemicals, although some practical
implementation and commercialization have been attempted, it is still not sufficient to reach the
requirements of environmental and market economy. This is due to several challenges that
remain. At the macroscopic level, challenges include (1) the higher energy requirements for CO2 chemical/electrochemical conversion, (2) the lack of sufficient socio-economical driving forces,
such as the limited market size and investment-incentives, (3) the insufficient industrial
commitments to enhance CO2-basd chemicals, and (4) the insufficient technology maturity. Due to these issues, economic feasibility is far from adequate, especially for industrial-scale
implementation[48]. On the microscopic level; especially for research and development, technical
challenges such as insufficient fundamental understanding, low product selectivity, as well as
low efficiency and stability have been identified. Several important challenges can be
summarized as follows:
(1) Insufficient fundamental understanding. It is known that CO2 molecules are stable from
a thermodynamic and kinetic standpoint as that the activation of C=O bonds require large
amounts of energy. This chemical stability makes CO2 conversion difficult. Although significant research into the reaction mechanisms of CO2 conversion have been investigated through both experimental and theoretical approaches, many processes for CO2 conversion to fuels /chemicals are still unclear. More research in this area is necessary.
(2) Low product selectivity. Aside from the electrochemical conversion of CO2 at high
temperatures, low product selectivity is a difficult problem for CO2 conversion through aqueous and non-aqueous methods at low temperatures. Undesired chemicals are formed as by-products
that require further complex separation and purification. Although some of these conversion
methods can produce desirable product selectivity, many obstacles exist that severely limits the
stability and overall performance.
(3) Low efficiency. The efficiency of some conversion approaches are still not high enough
for practical applications. Typically, the efficiency of some photocatalytic or photo-
electrochemical processes for CO2 conversion is even lower than that in natural photosynthesis or in photocatalytic H2O splitting. Another example is that the overpotential for the CO2 electrochemical conversion method is normally too high to guarantee catalyst activities which
can limit the efficiency of CO2 conversion into chemicals/fuels.
(4) Low stability. The contradiction between activity and stability/durability of CO2
conversion methods have not been fully understood. For instance, a typical issue in high
temperature conversions with SOCs is the material degradation from delamination or poisoning
of electrode materials. Another typical case is the catalytic activity degradation of catalysts on
the electrode at low temperatures, which can result from catalyst poisoning or the blocking of
catalyst active sites. Up to now, material developments and fundamental studies have been
conducted to deal with stability issues; however, the research into this topic such as the
fundamentals of material behavior and degradation mechanisms as well as the development of
new suitable materials seems to be insufficient.
(5) Poor economic and technological feasibility especially in industrial-scale
implementation. There are still obstacles for scalable, long-term production such as low-
efficiency, high cost and space waste in existing CO2 conversion technologies. Although efforts have been taken to optimize the conversion systems, these technological advancements are still
not sufficient for wide practical applications. In particular, many conversion processes to produce
chemicals/fuels such as dimethyl carbonate and formic acid are unprofitable, which directly
limits commercial and industrial implementation.

sections.heading: 4. Summary and possible research directions for CO2 conversion technologies
sections.text:
To facilitate the research and development of CO2 conversion, this review provides a
comprehensive overview of advanced CO2 conversion technologies for the production of useful fuels/chemicals. The fundamentals of CO2 including molecule structure, thermodynamics and kinetics are summarized to explain its chemical stability, which is a direct obstacle for CO2 conversion. Various conversion technologies as well as enzymatic, mineralization,
photochemical/ photo-electrochemical, thermochemical and electrochemical processes are
classified and reviewed. Particularly, electrochemical technologies at both low temperatures and
high temperatures are considered and compared. Furthermore, economic feasibilities are
analyzed in light of various chemicals/fuels. Finally, technical and application challenges of CO2 conversion to useful fuels/chemicals are proposed. To overcome these challenges, several future
research directions are proposed as follows:
(1) Further fundamental understanding of the CO2 activation and conversion processes.
The mechanisms of CO2 activation/conversion need to be further studied through both theoretical modeling and experimental testing (especially in electrochemical processes). For theoretical
modeling, the transition states and elementary reactions in CO2 conversions need to be further defined and the rate-limiting step as well as the reaction pathways need to be controlled to
overcome conversion barriers. For example, the mechanisms of CO2 reduction and their relationship to reaction active site composition and structures should be fundamentally
understood to guide new material development. To mitigate catalyst or electrode material
degradation, further fundamental understandings of material behaviors and degradation
mechanisms in CO2 conversion processes is of great important, which can be further revealed by implementing some advanced techniques (eg. In-situ time-resolved spectroscopy, XCT (X-ray
computed tomography), VT-STM (Variable temperature scanning tunnelling microscope), LEIS
(Low-energy ion scattering spectroscopy), AP-XPS (Ambient pressure-X-ray photoelectron
spectroscopy), environmental TEM (Transmission electron microscopy) and SIMS (Secondary
ion mass spectroscopy)). For instance, SIMS in 3D model can be performed to display elemental
3D distributions with fast oxygen-incorporation paths and separation of electrode/electrolyte
interface regions to analyze the causes for degradation and guide new designs of electrodes.
Moreover, to better control the reactions of CO2 conversion kinetically, simulation techniques such as DFT and MD are needed to calculate energy barriers. With further understandings, it is
possible to develop new methods to enhance activity and develop mitigation strategies for
degradation.
(2) Enhancement of stability, activity and products selectivity by optimizing or exploring
advanced materials. Large amounts of investigations have been performed to improve the
activity, stability and products selectivity of CO2 conversion systems, with some progresses being achieved. However, these technological progresses are still insufficient for practical
applications. Breakthroughs are needed. Aside from further fundamental understandings and
optimizations of material performance, structural and morphological tailors of catalyst materials
in nanoscale and the exploration of appropriate innovative materials are also effective methods
for enhancing activity, stability and even products selectivity. For instance, the adsorption and
activation of CO2 onto the surface of catalyst used in photocatalytic/photo-electrochemical processes can be optimized by morphological tailor. The enzymes used in enzymatic process
should be modified and immobilized to reduce the cost and improve the activity/stability. With
respect to electrochemical process in high temperature, mixed ionic and electronic conductors
(MIECs) and perovskites are needed to be widely studied to improve oxygen electrode
performances. For example, the hetero-structured perovskite materials can exhibit remarkable
enhancements in oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) kinetics, with three orders of magnitude
greater than that of previously used materials[249-252].
(3) Optimizing electrodes, system designs, and reactors for practical applications. Aside
from the materials themselves, the major limitations to activity and stability are partially related
to operating environments and/or reaction processes, which largely depend on the design of
reactors. In addition to improving material stability and activity, improving reactor designs and
exploring novel appropriate reactors is important for performance enhancements. As an example
mentioned above, the CO2 mineralization system can be designed to generate electricity and produce industrial valuable products simultaneously, which is economically feasible and
environmentally friendly. Regarding the electrochemical process, certain novel designs for SOC
configurations can lower ohmic and polarization resistances and enhance the power densities of
SOC stacks. Another case in point is that certain designs for electrolyte membrane-based and gas
diffusion electrodes (GDEs) electrochemical cells might be the right approaches to reduce
internal resistance and improve reactant mass transfer.
(4) Development of the CO2 conversion at intermediate temperature. As mentioned earlier,
although CO2 conversions at low temperatures (＜200 ℃) in aqueous and non-aqueous
techniques such as transition metal electrodes in liquid electrolytes or proton exchange
membranes typically can be applied with simpler materials and rapid starts in milder condition,
the system is complex and most catalysts are costly (especially catalysts containing Pt). By
contrast, CO2 conversion techniques at high temperatures (＞800 ℃) such as SOCs typically can
perform with superior product selectivity and efficiency. However, requirements for materials
including electrodes, electrolytes, seals and interconnects are much higher, and the stack lifetime
needs further verification due to degradation during high-temperature operations. Therefore, to
enhance conversion efficiency, product selectivity and stability, it is vitally important to draw on
each other’s strengths. It is believed that CO2 conversion at intermediate temperatures (300- 700 ℃) is an important and promising trend where materials such as catalysts, electrodes and
electrolyte materials need to be developed to fulfill the requirements for CO2 conversion process at intermediate temperatures.
(5) Developing the connection between CO2 conversion systems and other clean energy
sources. If clean energy sources such as nuclear, solar, wind and geothermal, etc. are used to run
CO2 conversion into useful chemicals/fuels, CO2 emission and energy shortage issues can be
relieved along with providing better economic feasibility. For instance, the conversion of CO2 into valuable fuels (e.g. CH4, CH3OH, HCOOH, etc.) via artificial photosynthesis can be performed using solar energy in large scale. And the co-electrolysis of CO2 and H2O can be performed to produce useful fuels of CO and H2 using solid oxide electrolysis cell stacks running on electricity and heat from redundant nuclear energy. Although efforts have been taken to
accelerate these developments, wider and scalable applications have a long way to go with
coupling techniques between CO2 conversion systems and other clean energy sources playing a key role. The implementation of this connection is difficult and requires worldwide government
support.

metadata.abstractText: CO2 conversion to produce useful fuels/chemicals is a promising route for reducing CO2 emission as well as for exploring the promising energy storage method. To facilitate the research and development of CO2 conversion, this paper provides a comprehensive overview of CO2 conversions using advanced materials/nanomaterials and technologies for the production of useful fuels/chemicals. The molecular structure, thermodynamics and kinetics of CO2 are reviewed for the understanding of fundamentals and explaining why C=O double bonds are difficult to break. The mechanisms and features of various conversion technologies are summarized and classified into enzymatic, mineralization, photochemical/photo-electrochemical, thermochemical as well as electrochemical processes. In particular, by comparing electrochemical conversion technologies at low and high temperatures, CO2 conversion at intermediate temperatures is emphasized. Furthermore, the economic feasibility for CO2 utilization is analyzed with cases for the production of various chemicals/fuels. The technical and application challenges of CO2 conversion into useful fuels/chemicals are also summarized, composing mainly of: insufficient fundamental understanding, low product selectivity, as well as low efficiency and stability. To overcome these challenges, future research directions are proposed in this review.
